Adapters¶

The Authomatic library is based on processing HTTP request, serving HTTP responses, url fetches, session management and database access. Most of which functionality is available in allmost all Python web frameworks.

Adapters just unify different interfaces to this functionality across frameworks.

When using this library you only need to choose an adapter for your framework and pass it’s instance to the authomatic.login() function.

Note

Currently there is only the gae.Webapp2Adapter available. If you need an adapter for another framework your contributions are very welcome. Implementing an adapter is very easy for a framework expert.

Google App Engine Adapters¶

Adapters and utilities to be used on Google App Engine.

authomatic.adapters.gae.ndb_config()[source]¶

Allows you to have a datastore Config instead of a hardcoded one.

This function creates an “Example” entity of kind “NDBConfig” in the datastore if the model is empty and raises and error to inform you that you should populate the model with data.

Note

The Datastore Viewer in the _ah/admin/ wont let you add properties to a model if there is not an entity with that property already. Therefore it is a good idea to keep the “Example” entity (which has all possible properties set) in the datastore.

Raises :GAEError
Returns:NDBConfig
class authomatic.adapters.gae.Webapp2Adapter(handler, session=None, session_secret=None, session_key='authomatic', openid_store=None)[source]¶

Adapter to be used with the Webapp2 framework on Google App Engine.

Note

You must provide session or session_secret.

Parameters:
  • handler – A Webapp2 RequestHandler instance.
  • session – A Webapp2 session.
  • session_secret (str) – Session secret.
  • session_key (str) – A key under which a new session will be created.
  • openid_store – Your own implementation of the openid.store.interface.OpenIDStore of the python-openid library. Default is gae.openid.NDBOpenidStore.

Implement Adapters¶

Implementing an adapter for a Python web framework is easy.

You do it by subclassing the BaseAdapter abstract class. There are only nine members that you need to implement and the only complicated one is the BaseAdapter.openid_store.

Moreover if your framework is based on the WebOb library you can use the WebObBaseAdapter and you only need to implement three members.

class authomatic.adapters.BaseAdapter[source]¶

Base class for platform adapters

Defines common interface for platform specific non standard library functionality.

url[source]¶

Must return the url of the actual request including path but without query and fragment

Returns:str
params[source]¶

Must return a dictionary of all request parameters of any HTTP method.

Returns:dict
write(value)[source]¶

Must write specified value to response.

Parameters:value (str) – String to be written to response.
Returns:dict
set_header(key, value)[source]¶

Must set response headers to Key: value.

Parameters:
  • key (str) – Header name.
  • value (str) – Header value.
redirect(url)[source]¶

Must issue a http 302 redirect to a specified URL.

Parameters:url (str) – URL to be redirected to.
session[source]¶

A session object with BaseSession or dict interface.

Returns:Session dictionary.
response_parser(response, content_parser)[source]¶

Must convert platform specific URL fetch response to core.Response.

Warning

Must be a classmethod!

Parameters:
  • response – Result of platform specific URL fetch call.
  • content_parser (function) – should be passed to core.Response constructor.
Returns:

core.Response
openid_store[source]¶

A permanent storage abstraction with openid.store.interface.OpenIDStore interface of the python-openid library.

Note

Required only by the OpenID provider so it is a good idea to use conditional import.

Returns:An object with the openid.store.interface.OpenIDStore interface.
fetch_async(url, payload=None, method='GET', headers={}, response_parser=None, content_parser=None)[source]¶

Must return an instance of the AsynchronousFetch class.

Note

If your framework doesn’t support asynchronous calls do it like this:

def fetch_async(self, url, payload=None, method='GET',headers={},
                response_parser=None, content_parser=None):
    
    # A dummy rpc object
    rpc = lambda: None
    # Make the synchronous fetch on the get_result() call.
    rpc.get_result = lambda: your_framework.fetch()
    
    return adapters.AsynchronousFetch(rpc, self, response_parser, content_parser)
Parameters:
  • url (str) – URL to fetch.
  • payload (str) – Body of the request.
  • method (str) – HTTP method of the request.
  • headers (dict) – Dictionary of HTTP headers of the request.
  • response_parser (function) – The response_parser(). Should be passed to the AsynchronousFetch constructor.
  • content_parser (function) – Should be passed to the AsynchronousFetch constructor.
Returns:

AsynchronousFetch
class authomatic.adapters.WebObBaseAdapter[source]¶

Abstract base class for adapters for WebOb based frameworks.

If you use this base class you only need to implement these three BaseAdapter members:

  • BaseAdapter.fetch_async()
  • BaseAdapter.response_parser()
  • BaseAdapter.openid_store
request[source]¶

Must be a WebOb Request.

response[source]¶

Must be a WebOb Response.

class authomatic.adapters.AsynchronousFetch(rpc_object, adapter, response_parser, content_parser)¶

Represents an asynchronous URL fetch call.

Parameters:
  • rpc_object – Any object that has a get_result() method.
  • adapter – The adapter instance.
  • response_parser (function) – The BaseAdapter.response_parser().
  • content_parser (function) – Should be passed to the AsynchronousFetch constructor.
get_response()¶

Returns Response instance
